key_points: U.S. military suspended all flights at Hamid Karzai International Airport due to chaos and security concerns.
Operations resumed on the military side later on Monday, but the civilian side stayed closed.
Crowds chased a C-17 airlifter, and U.S. troops faced gunfire from unknown gunmen at the airport.
Marine Corps Gen. Frank McKenzie, head of U.S. Central Command, warned the Taliban against attacks.
Taliban spokesman Suhail Shaheen stated they won't attack Americans or block Afghans from leaving.
Videos on Twitter purportedly showed people clinging to a C-17 and bodies falling as it took off.
U.S. forces engaged in gunfire at the airport, resulting in two deaths.
About 6,000 U.S. troops will be in Kabul to facilitate evacuations, with 500 arriving on Monday.
The U.S. plans to evacuate up to 5,000 people per day once flights fully resume.
The U.S. aims to house up to 22,000 Afghan special immigration visa applicants and other vulnerable Afghans.
